meeting_annotations.speaker: Jarad Mason
meeting_annotations.transcript: Based on my past experience with post combustion carbon capture it seemed like it would be really hard to have a porous material that you actually use to permanently sequester CO2 and that anything would have to be you know you would need be using the porous material just to separate out the CO2 and it would have to be reversible and the only thing that seemed viable on any kind of scale that would be significant would be just to sequester CO2 underground in like empty aquifers and and other things like you mentioned. meeting_annotations.speaker: Greeshma Gadikota
meeting_annotations.transcript: So Jared I have a question for you. I know people have looked at MOFs for hydrogen storage and methane storage that's been widely studied but I was wondering if people have actually looked at MOFs for not capture but just storing CO2. So you could actually you know if you are in a remote area where you have direct air capture maybe you could try to store the CO2 ship it to a nearby location and use that captured CO2 for something else. I mean as an alternative to a pipeline. Is that something that's been explored studied? Is that something of interest or is it even feasible?
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: Sarbarit Banerjee's screen share of the document titled "3. new ideas in negative emission CO2 utilization" continues. No changes are made to the content.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jarad Mason
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah so it's it's not been something that's been like a focus of research in the MOF community at least but the data that one would need to evaluate the storage potential of a MOF for CO2 is basically the same as what one would need for evaluating its separation potential. So similar type of thing. So it certainly is viable just as MOFs are viable for storing methane and things like that. So I guess yeah if you yeah if you selectively capture CO2 from some sort of point source and then you would certainly be able to store it in the MOF and transfer it to another location. And yeah people have looked at a lot of like natural gas purification type things where you have like sour natural gas streams right so high pressure sources of CO2 and trying to make MOFs that will selectively store CO2 under high pressure conditions and that's kind of analogous to I guess what you would be thinking about if you wanted to have like a compressed CO2 storage stream so you could store like a really high density such that it was more efficient to to transport it or things like that. Um but that's certainly something that could be possible. I think yeah the parameters that you would need to optimize in a MOF for CO2 storage are basically the same as a reversible separation. Um so a lot of the MOFs that are are good for that um would similarly probably be good for um that kind of storage application.

So if you can just try to store it in a material and then regenerate that material for a utilization purpose that might be and this is particularly in the context of distribution distributed manufacturing right?
